name: Swing, swing!
intro: Let's move some arguments around.
Just like in many chess and math problems, work backwards:
what λ-expression do you want to see before applying to the last argument?
Then construct it via the above technique and go one argument back,
until you run out of them.

content.name: Lost at GoF, found at g∘f
intro: The combinator application is not associative, i.e. (x y) z != x (y z)
(find examples!). However, a different operation is: composition.
And it will be used extensively in the subsequent quests, so buckle up...
...and provide a composition term: B f g x = f(g x),
also known as the Bluebird.
content.hint: You have already built a term that make f(g x) from known f. Break it down so that f is in the last place!

content.name: Blackbird singing in the dead of night
intro: Here comes Bluebird's cousin, Blackbird: B1 a b c d = a (b c d).
Unfortunately, this small and simple interpreter does not support indexed terms,
so no shortcut will be unlocked in this quest.
content.hint: Use B to move the last term in the parentheses outside and see what is left.

content.name: Mirror image
content.intro: Make a combinator T that swaps its two arguments, that is, (x, y) → y x

content.name: What you like, do once more!
content.intro: The W combinator is defined as x ⇒ y ⇒ x(y)(y). Implement it.

content.name: K forte
intro: Sometimes returning x for any given y is not enough.
Return it twice: (x, y)→x x.
Note: you should avoid applying x to itself until the next argument is given.

content.name: Round Robin
intro: The Robin bird, R, puts its first argument after the next two:
R x y z = y z x.

content.name: Ã‰minence grise
intro: The King passes the judgement, but the Cardinal dictates the order of execution.
Derive the C combinator, or Cardinal: C x y z = x z y.

content.name: Double patience
intro: The V combinator, aka vireo bird, takes two arguments and waits patiently
for a function to apply them to: V x y z = z x y.

content.name: The trident of Poseidon
intro: Create a term that takes three arguments and applies the forth to them:
f a b c d = d a b c.
This combinator has no common name, so we'll just call it v3.
It might come in handy later.
